Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2013
Award.AbstractNarration:
Building a bird: developmental and evolutionary construction of the avian body plan

In the process of acquiring the ability to fly, birds and their dinosaur ancestors have undertaken some of the most dramatic morphological and functional transformations in vertebrate history. Flight is the most challenging form of locomotion, and living adult birds have unique anatomical features that permit them to meet the demands of aerial locomotion. Early winged dinosaurs lacked many of these features, and consequently, it has long been assumed that early dinosaurs were incapable of powered flight. Yet baby birds with dinosaur-like anatomies elude predators by flap-running up slopes and even briefly flying. How is this accomplished? Whereas locomotion of adult animals is well studied, very little is known about locomotion of animals with transitional (developing or evolving) anatomies. Many features change during development and evolution, and parsing out their effects on locomotion is challenging. However, biomechanical modeling with programs like SIMM allows scientists to explore the functional consequences of changes in anatomical design, by manipulating anatomical parameters individually to determine their effects. Using birds and dinosaurs as a case study, this project aims to bridge biological, paleontological, and engineering disciplines to explore biomechanical underpinnings of developmental and evolutionary transformations in locomotor capacity and ecology.

The primary training objectives are: learning bioengineering approaches to examine form-function relationships and gaining experience making museum exhibits that let students see science in action. Anticipated outcomes include an exhibit that helps students build a digital dinosaur to explore how changes in anatomy might affect locomotion and presentations to academic and public audiences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Flight is the most physically challenging form of locomotion. This was immediately apparent to early aviators, and in modern adult birds these challenges are met with a suite of unusual anatomical features that are traditionally viewed as “adaptations” for flight. In contrast, both early winged theropods (the ancestors of birds) and immature, developing birds lack many of these flight adaptations: instead of large wings they have small “protowings”, and instead of the robust, interlocking wing skeleton associated with powerful flight, their limbs are more gracile and their joints less constrained. Such traits are often thought to preclude extinct theropods from powered flight, yet young birds with “dinosaur-like” anatomies flap-run up slopes and even briefly fly, thereby challenging longstanding ideas on skeletal and feather function in the theropod-avian lineage. How do developing birds accomplish flapping behaviors in the apparent absence of “flight adaptations”? What anatomical features are actually necessary for flight? These are important questions whether considering the development or the evolution of flight, but scientists do not yet have answers. One of the main reasons for this uncertainty is that many anatomical features (wings, muscles, skeletons) change during development and evolution. Deciphering how each of these changes contributes to flight performance is impossible to determine in live animals, since all features change simultaneously and their effects cannot be isolated. Biomechanical modeling, however, allows scientists to explicitly examine the functional consequences of changes in anatomical design, by manipulating anatomical parameters individually to determine their effects on locomotion. It is also one of the best methods for reconstructing locomotion in extinct animals. This project therefore uses a biomechanical modeling technique called SIMM (Software for Interactive Musculoskeletal Modeling) to determine how changes in anatomical design influence the developmental and evolutionary acquisition of flight capacity (flightless baby bird or dinosaur -> flight-capable adult bird or dinosaur). Project findings are helping elucidate the development and evolution of avian locomotion by (i) establishing how muscular and aerodynamic forces interface with the skeletal system to generate movement in morphing juvenile birds (impossible to determine in live animals), and (ii) providing a benchmark to inform biomechanical modeling and simulation of extinct theropod dinosaurs with similar anatomies. By integrating work on live animals with fossils and biomechanical modeling, this project advances our understanding of the functional significance of developmental and evolutionary precursors to wings and other “organs of extreme perfection”. This type of work is applicable to a broad array of vertebrate species, and will serve as a case study to show how quantifying developmental transitions in form and function can provide important insight into patterns along the tree of life.

Results of this project are being extensively used in public outreach. Public audiences are always interested in dinosaurs and baby animals, and AMH is using this research to foster public interest in science through public talks (e.g., "Hack the Dinosaurs” 2015) and museum exhibits ("Dinosaurs Among Us").“Dinosaurs Among Us” opens at the American Museum of Natural History in spring of 2016, and will feature a video interview of AMH speaking about bird development and biomechanical modeling, as well as a computer interactive, co-designed by AMH, that will allow visitors to "build a bird" with various anatomical features, see whether or not it could fly, and compare it both to extant birds and extinct dinosaurs.
